title: iHuman Lab Manual
text:
Welcome
We‚Äôre so excited you‚Äôve joined the Intelligent Human-Machine Nexus Lab (aka iHuman Lab)! üöÄ Get ready to dive into the fascinating world of human-machine interaction and neuroscience. Along the way, you‚Äôll pick up awesome skills (think coding, data analysis, writing papers, and giving epic talks), make new friends, and have a blast!
We know that starting in a research lab can feel like drinking from a firehose üåä‚Äîbut don‚Äôt worry, we‚Äôve got your back! This manual is your trusty sidekick, guiding you through everything from lab policies to your rights and responsibilities. You‚Äôll also find tips on how to fit right in with our workflows, stay safe, and keep things ethical.

title: iHuman Lab Manual
text:
Acknowledgments
Big thanks to the following labs for inspiring parts of this manual: Context Dynamics Lab The Memory Modulation Lab Aly Lab Peelle Lab Ritchey Lab Kemp Lab
This manual is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License, which means you can share, adapt, and remix it‚Äîjust be sure to give credit where credit‚Äôs due!

title: Introduction
text:
Who is this lab manual for?
Every new lab member should read this manual in detail and refer back to it as needed. As you go through it, you‚Äôll see Task items‚Äîthese are action points for you to complete.
To finish your read-through, you‚Äôll need to:
This manual is a living document, so feel free to contribute edits to make it better for everyone!

title: Introduction
text:
Read the entire manual.
Ask lab members if anything‚Äôs unclear.
Complete the Task items.
Take note of the NOTE sections‚Äîthey‚Äôre packed with helpful tips and extra context.

title: Introduction
section: What to do if you don‚Äôt understand something?
text:
What to do if you don‚Äôt understand something?
Don‚Äôt hesitate to ask a lab member for clarification! Each of us brings unique experiences and perspectives that help drive our research. If you‚Äôre new to something, there‚Äôs a good chance others have been where you are and can help out. Plus, if something doesn‚Äôt make sense, you might just spot an error or inconsistency!






Task



After your first read-through, update the Lab Members section with your name. Be sure to fork the GitHub repository, edit your personal fork, and submit a pull request with your update!

title: Introduction
section: Why should I read this manual?
text:
Why should I read this manual?
Aside from satisfying your curiosity, you‚Äôre probably here to gain valuable training and experience to advance your career. This manual compiles the wisdom of past and present lab members to help you achieve those goals. Learn from it, challenge it, and add to it!

title: Introduction
text:
What isn‚Äôt this lab manual?
This isn‚Äôt a comprehensive guide to every detail of your research project. You might not even know everything you‚Äôll need to know right away‚Äîbut this is where your journey starts!
If you need more detailed guidance, check out our lab‚Äôs tutorials. And if you discover something new and helpful, consider contributing your own tutorial to help others!

title: Introduction
text:
Research Project Manual
Alongside this general manual, you‚Äôll also use the Research Project Manual for in-depth guidance on coding, writing research papers, data management, project structuring, and more. This resource is key to making sure our research is precise, thorough, and top-notch at every stage.

title: Lab Member Roles
text:
PI (Principal Investigator)
The PI is the brain behind the lab‚Äîthe one who keeps everything running:

title: Lab Member Roles
text:
Fundraising Genius: Secures funding to keep the lab alive and thriving.
Research Coach: Meets with you regularly (usually once a week) to discuss your projects and guide your academic journey.
Career Booster: Helps you with professional development by connecting you with other researchers, writing recommendation letters, and promoting your work at conferences.
Human First: Cares about you as a person, not just a researcher.

title: Lab Member Roles
text:
Project Owner
The Project Owner is the visionary‚Äîthe one who ensures the project is moving in the right direction and achieving results:

The Visionary: Keeps the project‚Äôs big picture in mind and sets the research goals.
The Prioritizer: Constantly adjusts the research priorities and long-term goals, including publication plans.
The Decision-Maker: Makes final calls on project requirements, whether to publish, and whether to keep pushing forward with development.
The Guardian of Interests: Considers funding bodies and the scientific community‚Äôs needs in every decision.
The Leader: Guides the team but might still roll up their sleeves and contribute as a team member.

title: Lab Member Roles
text:
Team Member
Team Members are the engine that powers the project. They do the hands-on work and collaborate closely:

Cross-functional All-Stars: Write code, collect data, test software, proofread papers‚Äîwhatever the project needs!
Self-Managing: Organize and manage themselves, without needing a boss to tell them what to do.
Collaborative: Work intensely with others in the team (think: constant communication, shared problem-solving).
Commitment: Ideally, they focus on one project at a time and stay with the lab for the long haul.
Leadership: Even as contributors, Team Members have a leadership role in driving their area of the project.

title: Lab Member Roles
text:
Project Coordinator
The Project Coordinator is the glue that keeps everything together, making sure the team is staying on track and that the research process is smooth:

Impediment-Buster: Helps remove any roadblocks that could slow down the team.
Environment Creator: Ensures the team has the space and freedom to self-organize and thrive.
Data Guru: Tracks progress and adjusts forecasts (you‚Äôll see weekly updates in Microsoft Teams).
Team Shield: Protects the team from distractions, so they can stay focused.
Timeline Enforcer: Keeps an eye on deadlines and ensures the project stays on track.
No Authority: The Project Coordinator has no formal management power over the team‚Äîthey‚Äôre more like a helpful guide. (For now, that‚Äôs usually the Lab Coordinator or Hemanth).

title: Lab Member Roles
text:
Collaborator
Collaborators are the specialists who offer occasional help but aren‚Äôt fully embedded in the project:

The Helper: May provide data, equipment, consulting, feedback, minor analyses, or administrative support (like scheduling).
The Backstage Player: They aren‚Äôt involved in day-to-day project decisions and generally don‚Äôt attend regular meetings.
Paper Recognition: If their contribution is significant enough, they may be mentioned in acknowledgments, but usually not as co-authors.

Collaborators are a big help when needed, but they stay in the background unless they‚Äôre ready to step up into a bigger role.

title: Code of Conduct
text: The Quick Version

title: Code of Conduct
text:
We are committed to creating a harassment-free space for all lab members and visitors, regardless of gender, age, race, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, or religion.
Harassment is not tolerated in any form‚Äîwhether verbal, physical, or emotional.
Sexual language and imagery are inappropriate in all lab spaces, including meetings, presentations, or casual conversations.

title: Code of Conduct
text:
The Less Quick Version
Harassment includes:

Offensive comments related to gender, age, appearance, race, religion, etc.
Sexual images or language in public spaces.
Intimidation, stalking, and unwelcome attention (verbal or physical).
Disruptions during talks, meetings, or events.
Inappropriate contact or unwanted physical behavior.

If asked to stop any harassing behavior, you must comply immediately.
If you‚Äôre experiencing or witnessing harassment‚Äîor have any concerns‚Äîplease contact Hemanth right away. If Hemanth is the issue, reach out to the department chair or another trusted staff member.

title: Code of Conduct
text:
The Bottom Line
We expect all members to uphold these guidelines at all lab-related events. Let‚Äôs work together to keep our environment safe, welcoming, and productive!
(Adapted from Lab Code of Conduct)

Respect is key! Let‚Äôs keep it fun and professional, always. üöÄ

title: Getting Started in the Lab
text:
Lab website
Once you have your accounts set up, you‚Äôll need to add your profile to the lab‚Äôs website. Follow these steps to fork the repository, create your profile folder, and add your details.

title: Getting Started in the Lab
text:
Step 1: Fork the Lab Website Repository

Go to the lab website GitHub repository.
Click on the Fork button in the top-right corner of the page. This will create a copy of the repository under your own GitHub account.



Step 2: Clone Your Forked Repository

On your GitHub account, navigate to your forked repository.
Click the Code button and copy the repository URL.
Open your terminal and clone the repository to your local machine using:
git clone https://github.com/iHuman-Lab/lab-website.git
Navigate to the repository directory:
cd lab-website



Step 3: Add Your Profile Folder

In the people directory, find the folder corresponding to your role in the lab:
people/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ pi/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ phd/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ master/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ undergraduate/
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ alumni/
If you are a master student, create a new folder with your name under the master directory. Replace "your_name" with your actual name:
mkdir -p people/master/"your_name"
For other roles, replace master with pi, phd, undergraduate, or alumni accordingly.



Step 4: Add Your Profile Details

Inside your folder (e.g., people/master/"your_name"), add your profile photo and index file.
Your photo should be named avatar.jpg. Add this photo to your folder:
cp path/to/your/photo.jpg people/master/"your_name"/avatar.jpg
Create an index.qmd file in the same folder. Use the following content template for index.qmd:
---
title: Your name here
about:
    template: trestles
    links:
        - icon: linkedin
          text: LinkedIn
          url: Add your linkedin link
        - icon: github
          text: Github
          url: Add your Github link
        - text: "{{< ai google-scholar >}} Google Scholar"
          url: If you have google scholar link, add it here.
        - text: Website
          url: If you have a website link, add it here.
image: ./avatar.jpg
---

## Education
Fill your education history here

## Research Interest
Provide your research interest
Replace placeholders like Your name here, Add your linkedin link, etc., with your actual details.



Step 5: Commit and Push Your Changes

Commit your changes:
git commit -m "Add profile for [Your Name]"
Push your changes to your forked repository:
git push origin main



Step 6: Create a Pull Request

Go to your forked repository on GitHub.
Click on the Pull Requests tab and then New Pull Request.
Select the base repository as iHuman-Lab/lab-website and compare it with your forked repository.
Add a description for your pull request and submit it.

üéâ Congrats‚Äîyou‚Äôre officially part of the lab online! If you get stuck, just ping Hemanth on Teams.

title: Scientific Integrity
text: Reproducibility: The Holy Grail

title: Scientific Integrity
text:
Reproducible research means that anyone, anywhere, should be able to reproduce your results if they follow the same process and use the same data.
This requires organization and meticulous documentation‚Äîso be detailed in recording every step of your research journey!
While replicability (getting the same result with a different dataset) is great, reproducibility is our minimum standard.

title: Scientific Integrity
text:
Transparency & Openness

Open science: Share your data so others can verify and build upon it.
Publish in accessible journals and platforms to make your findings available to all.
Be clear and detailed about your methods and analytical approaches so others can replicate or extend your work.

title: Scientific Integrity
section: Ethical Conduct: Be a Science Superhero
text:
Ethical Conduct: Be a Science Superhero

Always ensure informed consent and protect participants‚Äô privacy.
Report methods, results, and potential conflicts of interest openly and honestly.
Follow ethical guidelines and field-specific regulations.

title: Scientific Integrity
text:
Reproducibility & Rigor

Keep meticulous records: from your methods and procedures to your data management.
Validate findings through independent replication and robust statistical analyses.
Double-check everything with quality control to minimize errors and biases.

title: Making Mistakes
text: Why It‚Äôs OK to Make Mistakes (But Important to Report)

title: Making Mistakes
text:
Mistakes are unavoidable, and they don‚Äôt mean failure‚Äîthey‚Äôre opportunities to learn.
Reporting them immediately minimizes the impact and helps us correct course early.
Think of it like this: ‚ÄúThe best time to fix a mistake was earlier, the second best time is now!‚Äù

title: Making Mistakes
section: Example Scenarios (and how to handle them)
text:
Example Scenarios (and how to handle them)

You found a bug in your code after sharing a figure/statistic

Verify: Double-check the code and results.
Report: Create a GitHub issue with all the details.
Collaborate: Let the team know so you can fix it together.

The experiment crashed or corrupted data

Verify: Check if the data is salvageable or if a redo is needed.
Report: Document the issue so the team knows and can avoid it next time.
Collaborate: Discuss with others on Microsoft Teams to troubleshoot.

You found a typo in a paper you‚Äôve shared

Verify: Reread the document and confirm the error.
Report: If it‚Äôs minor, just correct and update the file.
Collaborate: Ask for a second pair of eyes from the team for a more thorough review.

Your project plan has a flaw or needs improvement

Verify: Review the plan and identify any improvements.
Report: Discuss changes with the team and update the plan.
Collaborate: Share new ideas and work together to improve the approach.

You released a software package with an error

Verify: Reproduce the issue and assess the extent.
Report: Post the error on GitHub and document the bug.
Collaborate: Work with the team to fix it and release a patch.

title: Making Mistakes
section: The Action Steps: What to Do Immediately
text:
The Action Steps: What to Do Immediately

Verify: Confirm the mistake before jumping to conclusions.
Report: Use GitHub or other tools to document the error.
Collaborate: Talk with the team on Microsoft Teams to brainstorm solutions.
Seek Guidance: Don‚Äôt be afraid to ask for help‚Äîsometimes the best ideas come from others.

Mistakes are part of being a researcher, so let‚Äôs celebrate them as learning moments. By fostering an environment of open communication, collaboration, and growth, we ensure our work is always improving. ‚ú®

title: Communication
text: Two Common Barriers to Communication

title: Communication
text:
Fear of asking questions:

Concern: ‚ÄúIf I ask this, will I look inexperienced?‚Äù
Reality: No! It‚Äôs far worse to stay silent when you‚Äôre stuck. Speaking up is the fastest way to resolve issues and improve. We all want you to succeed, so ask questions and share challenges‚Äîyou‚Äôll get there faster by working together.

Fear of ‚Äúbothering‚Äù someone senior:

Concern: ‚ÄúAm I bothering the grad student/postdoc/PI by asking this?‚Äù
Reality: Don‚Äôt worry about bothering me or anyone else. I prefer that you speak up rather than stay quiet. We‚Äôre all here to support each other. If you‚Äôre unsure, I‚Äôll let you know if you‚Äôre really bothering me (so far, that hasn‚Äôt happened yet!).

title: Communication
text:
Why Speaking Up Helps You

Increased productivity: Discussing problems and challenges helps you avoid getting stuck.
More support: The more you communicate, the more we can help you and work together to solve problems.
Growth: Learning to ask the right questions and talk through issues is a skill that makes you stronger as a researcher.

title: Communication
text:
Work Hours & Communication

Weekends/after hours: I don‚Äôt expect responses outside of normal hours (unless there‚Äôs a clear, urgent deadline or event). I may send messages, but don‚Äôt feel pressured to reply until you‚Äôre back in work mode.
Urgency: If something critical comes up (e.g., paper submission, conference presentation), we‚Äôll discuss strategies in advance, so you‚Äôre not left guessing.

title: Lab Meetings
text: Weekly Lab Meetings

title: Lab Meetings
text:
When: Tuesdays from 1:30 - 2:30 PM (CST), starting in Fall 2025
Where: ATRC 324
Attendance: All active lab members should attend unless there‚Äôs a conflict (let Hemanth know if you can‚Äôt make it). These meetings are important for keeping the lab connected, informed, and collaborative.

title: Lab Meetings
text:
Presentation Expectations

Present once per term: As an active member, you‚Äôll present at least one lab meeting each term. It can be anything related to your work or something cool you‚Äôve discovered!

Possible topics include:

A half-baked idea or a topic you‚Äôre exploring
A paper you found intriguing
A tool or software package you learned about
A tutorial or brief skill share
A hackathon update or project progress
Something you‚Äôre confused about‚Äîask for feedback!
Practice presentations: Talk or poster you‚Äôd like input on

You can take up to an hour, but shorter is fine! You can also co-present with a teammate if you like. Hemanth will send out a Google Sheets link for scheduling at the start of each term.

title: Lab Meetings
text:
Project Meetings
These are organized as needed for specific projects. Whether you‚Äôre collaborating within the lab or with external partners, these meetings are all about coordination and progress.

Attendees: Core project team + any interested lab members

title: Lab Meetings
text:
Hackathons
We occasionally hold hackathon-style events‚Äîspontaneous, high-energy, short-term projects. These are a great way to tackle a specific problem or idea in a collaborative, fast-paced way.

Attendees: Any interested lab members, Dartmouth community members, and external collaborators

title: Lab Meetings
text:
Weekly Snippets
Each week, all paid employees must fill out a quick weekly snippet with answers to the following:

What did you work on last week?
What are you planning to work on this coming week?
Is anything blocking your progress?
Anything else you want to add?

This keeps everyone aligned and helps us understand where support might be needed.

title: Travel Policy
text: If You‚Äôre Presenting Your Work

title: Travel Policy
text:
Travel Expenses & Conference Fees: If you‚Äôre the presenting author (talk or poster), the lab will cover your travel expenses and conference registration fees.
Seek Other Funding: We encourage you to seek additional travel funding through other channels (e.g., PBS, internal Dartmouth sources, travel awards, personal grants like NRSAs or NSF fellowships).
Keep It Reasonable: While we want to be mindful of your comfort and time, keep costs low. This might mean flying economy, finding affordable hotels, and sharing rooms with lab members when possible. We‚Äôll still ensure you‚Äôre comfortable!

title: Travel Policy
section: If You‚Äôre a Senior Lab Member (Not Presenting)
text:
If You‚Äôre a Senior Lab Member (Not Presenting)

Limited Support: If you‚Äôre not presenting but are a senior member (e.g., postdoc), the lab may cover your travel expenses to a limited number of conferences each year.
Discuss with Hemanth: Please talk to Hemanth about which conferences you‚Äôre interested in attending and whether funding is possible.

title: Travel Policy
section: If You‚Äôre a Junior Lab Member (Not Presenting)
text:
If You‚Äôre a Junior Lab Member (Not Presenting)

Funding Not Typically Provided: If you‚Äôre not presenting and you‚Äôre a junior member (e.g., undergrad or early-stage grad student), the lab typically does not cover travel expenses.
Explore Funding Options: If you really want to attend a conference, try to find external funding. If you can‚Äôt secure any, talk to Hemanth to explore your options.

title: Authorship guidelines
text:
Old projects
For projects that required significant lab resources (e.g., EEG studies or any other study requiring a great deal of time, money, or lab effort): Project ‚Äúownership‚Äù expires 3 years after data collection has ended (or whenever the original primary lead relinquishes their rights to the study, whichever comes first). At that point, I reserve the right to re-assign the project (or not) as needed to expedite publication. This policy is intended to avoid situations in which a dataset languishes for a long period of time while still giving publication priority to the original primary lead.

title: Deadlines
text:
Staying sane in academia is all about teamwork and timing! Think of deadlines as stormy seas‚Äîyour job is to spot the lighthouse early and signal the crew (yes, even bug Hemanth). Clear heads and timely nudges keep the ship sailing smoothly. Here are the ideal timelines:

Quick stuff (conference reviews, paperwork): 1 week‚Äôs notice.
Medium stuff (recommendation letters): 2 weeks.
Big stuff (research/teaching statements): 3 weeks.
Manuscripts: Share drafts ASAP! If feedback stalls past 2 weeks, a friendly reminder works wonders.







Tip



Track everything on Microsoft Planner‚Äîour shared compass for deadlines.

title: Lab Attendance
text: Attendance Expectations

title: Lab Attendance
text:
Be Present: We value your contributions and the collaborative nature of our work. Try to attend all scheduled lab sessions, meetings, and experiments as planned by Hemanth.
Team Effort: Each member‚Äôs attendance is important for the collective success of our research projects!

title: Lab Attendance
text:
Reporting Absences

Life Happens: We get it‚Äîsometimes things come up. If you can‚Äôt make a session or meeting due to illness, an emergency, or something unexpected, let Hemanth know ASAP.
Early Communication: The earlier we know, the easier it is to adjust plans and keep everything on track.

title: Lab Attendance
text:
Scheduling Flexibility

We‚Äôre Flexible: If you have a valid reason for needing a schedule adjustment, we‚Äôll work with you to accommodate your situation while keeping our research on track.

title: Lab Attendance
text:
Special Circumstances

Support During Hard Times: If you‚Äôre facing prolonged illness or a family emergency, reach out to Hemanth. We‚Äôll figure out how to best support you during tough times.


Your presence and contributions are what make iHuman Lab a success. We‚Äôre all in this together! Thank you for being such an important part of the team. üëè

title: Lab Traditions
text: Celebrations with Donuts and More!

title: Lab Traditions
text:
Sweet Moments: Whether you‚Äôve submitted a paper, won an award, or it‚Äôs your birthday, we mark these milestones with donuts for everyone! It‚Äôs our way of saying ‚Äúgreat job‚Äù and sharing in your success.
Welcoming Newbies: When new members join, Hemanth kicks things off with donuts, coffee, or tea at 4pm to make sure everyone feels at home from day one.

title: Lab Traditions
text:
Annual Lab Retreats

Bonding Beyond Science: Every year, we take a retreat to a destination chosen by the whole lab. It‚Äôs an opportunity to connect over science, hike, and play board games‚Äîbut also just to have fun and relax together.

title: Lab Traditions
text:
Other Events

We organize various other gatherings throughout the year, ensuring that everyone feels included and can participate in the fun! From team-building activities to social hangouts, there‚Äôs always something on the horizon.


We‚Äôre all about creating memorable experiences together, both inside and outside the lab. Let‚Äôs make the most of our time together and celebrate the little wins along the way! üéâ

title: Lab resources
text:
Computers
All lab members need a computer to get their work done. We generally prefer to use Linux machines, as this maximizes compatibility across lab members. Depending on your expected role in the lab and the specifics of your project, the lab may provide a computer to you, or you may be expected to use your personal computer to complete your work. Any equipment purchased by the lab, including personal computers, is the official property of the iHuman Lab and should be treated as such. All equipment must be returned to the lab when your association with the lab is complete. In addition to personal computers, we also maintain a lab account at Oklahoma State University‚Äôs Supercomputing Cluster.

title: Lab resources
text:
Other research equipment
Many research projects require specialized research equipment (e.g.¬†for neuroimaging using EEG, ECoG, etc.). Some of the necessary research equipment is owned by the iHuman Lab, and other equipment is shared with other labs affiliated with PBS or DHMC. All equipment should be treated with care and respect. Any malfunctions should be reported immediately.

title: Lab resources
section: Repository of shared lab papers and books
text:
Repository of shared lab papers and books
Our lab maintains a Dropbox repository of PDFs for internal use by lab members and affiliates. Contact Hemanth for a link (not to be shared publicly).

title: Checklist and signature page
text:
Congrats on making towards the end of the document. Please sign the below document and send it to ihuman.research.lab@gmail.com. Note that not all checkpoints might apply to you, check which ever applies.






Task




Review the research project manual which provides comprehensive guidance on coding practices, the procedure for writing research papers, managing data effectively, structuring research projects, and accessing valuable learning resources.
Create a pull request to add your photo and personal website to lab website. The procedure to add this is given in Lab website



Loading‚Ä¶

title: Rights and Responsibilities
text: Your Rights as a Lab Member

title: Rights and Responsibilities
text:
You‚Äôre entitled to a safe and respectful work environment‚Äîno harassment, abuse, violence, or discrimination.
You‚Äôre entitled to be supported and respected by all lab members.
You‚Äôre entitled to freely share your scientific ideas and offer constructive feedback.
You‚Äôre entitled to receive appropriate credit (authorship, acknowledgments, recommendations) for your contributions.

title: Rights and Responsibilities
section: Your Responsibilities as a Lab Member
text:
Your Responsibilities as a Lab Member

Promote a safe environment: Avoid any behavior that could harm, harass, or discriminate against others.
Support and respect everyone, including yourself.
Share your ideas and feedback openly with fellow lab members.
Document your contributions clearly: Whether it‚Äôs via GitHub, reports, or updates on Microsoft Teams, make sure your work is tracked.
Communicate openly: Address concerns directly with those involved, and always be clear with others about your work.
Work with integrity: Commit to high scientific standards in everything you do.
Use resources responsibly: Whether it‚Äôs time, equipment, or funding, make sure you‚Äôre being sustainable and considerate.
Keep your space clean: A tidy lab is a happy lab‚Äîclean up after yourself and maintain shared areas too!







Task



Read this letter on recognizing unhealthy lab dynamics and setting boundaries.

title: Rights and Responsibilities
text:
Big Picture

Do work you‚Äôre proud of‚Äîand work that others will care about.
Double-check your work: Good science requires a little obsession with detail.
Support your labmates: We‚Äôre a team, and teamwork makes the dream work.
Be independent when you can: But never hesitate to ask for help when you need it.
Share your knowledge: Mentorship comes in many forms.
Respect diversity: Honor each other‚Äôs strengths, weaknesses, and beliefs.
Take care of yourself: Science is a marathon. Take time off when needed, and respect others‚Äô personal time.
Communicate openly: Be transparent and respectful in all interactions.
Talk to Hemanth if you have an unresolved issue with a lab member.

title: Rights and Responsibilities
text:
Small Picture

Stay home if you‚Äôre sick: Get well and don‚Äôt risk spreading it.
Notify if you‚Äôre out: Let the lab manager or Hemanth know if you‚Äôre sick or on vacation. Update the lab calendar and your Microsoft Teams status.
No lab on staff holidays: Unless you‚Äôre on a paid contract during university breaks.
Lock up: Always lock the lab doors if you‚Äôre the last one to leave.
Keep it tidy: Clean up food messes, take dirty dishes home, and keep common areas clutter-free.
Dress code: Casual is fine, but look semi-professional when interacting with participants or presenting.
Arrive early: Aim to be in the lab 15 minutes before your experiments to greet participants.

title: Rights and Responsibilities
text:
Recourse
If you feel your rights have been violated‚Äîor if you see others‚Äô rights being compromised‚Äîit‚Äôs your duty to report it to a senior staff member (Hemanth, Department Chair, or even Title IX coordinator). Don‚Äôt stay silent‚Äîspeak up and help maintain a healthy, respectful environment.

title: Lab Practices & Policies
text: Collaboration

title: Lab Practices & Policies
text:
We‚Äôre all in this together. Our team‚Äôs diversity‚Äîfrom Computer Science to Neuroscience‚Äîhelps us tackle tough problems.
The key to success? Admitting what we don‚Äôt know and learning together!

title: Lab Practices & Policies
text:
Patience

Science is hard. Expect experiments to fail more than succeed‚Äîbut that‚Äôs where the magic happens.
Stay calm, keep thinking, and collaborate when things go wrong. If something‚Äôs not working, it‚Äôs okay to move on.

title: Lab Practices & Policies
text:
Accept the Process

Mistakes and unexpected results happen. Embrace them.
Facing issues head-on, figuring them out, and moving forward is the only way to grow!

title: Lab Practices & Policies
text:
Caution

Skepticism is key. Double-check everything.
Test your results from every angle to ensure you‚Äôre on the right track.

title: Lab Practices & Policies
text:
Attention to Detail

Small details can make or break an experiment.
Quality control is crucial to ensure things keep moving forward smoothly.

title: Lab Practices & Policies
text:
Communication

No one works alone here. Good communication keeps us on the same page.
Frequent updates help avoid misunderstandings and duplicated efforts.

title: Lab Practices & Policies
text:
Feedback

Constructive criticism is essential. It‚Äôs not personal‚Äîjust a way to improve!
Our goal is to find solutions, not prove how clever we are. Feedback fuels better science.

title: Lab Practices & Policies
text:
Positivity

Science is tough, but a positive attitude keeps the team energized.
